conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the Ampere force on the rod at the initial moment.
The problem does not provide the initial velocity of the rod.
Use the information given about the Joule heat generated on the resistor R between AB.
Calculate the total energy dissipated as Joule heat in the circuit as the sum of the energies dissipated in both resistors.
Since the resistors are in parallel, the total resistance is R_total = R/2.
The total energy dissipated as Joule heat is Q_total = 2Q.
Relate the total energy dissipated to the initial kinetic energy of the rod: E_k = 2Q.
The initial kinetic energy of the rod is given by E_k = 1/2 mv_0^2.
Setting the initial kinetic energy equal to the total energy dissipated, v_0 = sqrt(4Q/m).
Calculate the initial induced emf in the loop using Faraday's law: E = BLv_0.
Calculate the induced current in the loop: I = 2BLv_0/R.
Determine the initial Ampere force on the rod: F = BIL.
Substitute v_0 = sqrt(4Q/m) into the force equation to get F = 4B^2L^2 sqrt(Q/m)/R.
The magnitude of the Ampere force on the rod at the initial moment is 4B^2L^2 sqrt(Q/m)/R.
